The Baker.Action: Works hard alongside his wife, showing dedication and honesty in their shared goal of having a child.
Expresses sincere longing for a child, revealing vulnerability and emotional openness.
Narrates with insight about others' behavior, showing awareness and reflection.
Turns to see a small hand snatch a bun from the counter, implying tolerance or acceptance of the child's innocent action.
Scurries about the kitchen with his wife, indicating active effort and involvement in their work.
Passive voice narration without clear demonstration of problem-solving or leadership in this excerpt.
Stops Little Red Riding Hood from stealing a bun and listens to her request for bread for her grandmother.
Swiftly comes around the counter and directly addresses the girl who tries to take a bun, demonstrating attentiveness and control of his shop.
Responds to Little Red Riding Hood’s polite request for bread, showing courteous customer service and awareness of his business role.
Tries to wrest buns away from Little Red Riding Hood, shows concern about her eating too many sweets.
Comments to Wife about saving some sweets for Granny, indicating care for others.
Appears less enthusiastic than his Wife about Little Red Riding Hood's presence, showing mild reluctance.
Tries to manage the situation with Little Red Riding Hood, attempts to control the buns she is eating, and advises to save some for Granny.
Seems reluctant or less engaged with Little Red Riding Hood's presence compared to his wife who adores her.
Tries unsuccessfully to protect his wife from the threatening Witch.
Screams and cowers in a corner when confronted by the Witch, showing vulnerability but no aggression.
Asks the Witch what she wants, engaging respectfully despite the threat.
Opens the window a crack to identify who is at the door, showing caution and awareness.
Tries unsuccessfully to protect his wife when the Witch approaches, indicating a momentary failure or lack of effective action.
Asks the Witch what she wants after she dismisses bread, showing willingness to engage and seek information.
Appears alarmed and scared, cowering in a corner when the Witch arrives, showing fear and hesitation.
Expresses surprise and curiosity about family history, indicating openness.
His father stole from the Witch's garden, implicating family dishonesty but Baker himself does not perpetuate this behavior in excerpt.
Questions the Witch about having a sibling and asks where she is, showing curiosity and desire to understand his family history.
Shows no prior knowledge of his sister or past events related to his family, indicating lack of awareness or understanding of his own background.
Allows himself to be told difficult truths by the Witch without immediately challenging or resisting, showing a lack of assertiveness or control in crucial moments.
His father steals the Witch's beans, an act indirectly reflecting on the family but not the Baker himself.
The Witch places a spell on the Baker and his family thwarting their ability to have children, indicating challenges he faces.
Comforts his wife when she is weeping, expresses sorrow to her.
Expresses sorrow and empathy to his wife, apologizing for the hardships caused.
Questions the Witch about her betrayal, showing emotional response but also taking a stand.
Nods in agreement with his wife to reverse the curse, showing willingness to act for family.
Accepts the Witch’s demanding and dangerous task without complaint.
Nods in agreement with the Witch's demand to reverse the curse and accepts the dangerous quest without hesitation.
Appears passive in the face of overwhelming magical force (flung by the Witch), showing little resistance or strategy.
Refuses to wear his father's hunting jacket, expressing anger and rejection toward his father.
Rejects his wife's offer to help because he wants to do this task alone and protect her from danger.
Memorizes the list of items needed to lift the spell with care and determination.
Leaves home with his wife accompanying him, showing partnership and cooperation.
Memorizes the list of items needed to lift the spell.
Struggles to fully recall the items without prompting.
Refuses to take the cloak from Little Red Ridinghood, saying he can't just take it from a little girl.
Greets Little Red Ridinghood politely and engages in friendly conversation.
Expresses frustration ('This is ridiculous!') when ordered around by the Witch but continues to comply.
Unties the cape from Little Red Ridinghood quickly without asking further permission.
Hesitates to take the cape from Little Red Riding Hood, expressing moral reluctance and confusion about how to proceed, indicating uncertainty and lack of decisiveness.
Decides to approach Little Red Riding Hood directly to ask about the cape and manages to untie it quickly, showing initiative and some problem-solving skill.
Pulls the cape off LRRH and runs off with it, causing her to scream, but then stops cold, realizes his mistake, returns and sincerely apologizes by placing the cape around her shoulders.
Expresses distress and desperation when speaking about the impossibility of getting the items needed to lift the spell, showing vulnerability.
Pulls away when the Wife tries to help by tying a scarf around his neck, insisting that he alone can lift the spell on their house.
Politely initiates conversation with Jack and tries to understand the situation with the cow.
Appears uncertain about the value of the magic beans and invents vague information to convince Jack.
Checks his pockets for money and admits they have very little, showing practical awareness of their resources.
Relies on his wife to coach him on how to negotiate, indicating some lack of confidence or experience.
Hands Jack five beans despite reservations, showing a reluctant kindness.
Looks to his wife guiltily after giving Jack beans, indicating some emotional conflict and care.
Expresses doubt and warns against deceit, showing a value for honesty and sincerity.
Admits insecurity about being a father due to his father’s influence, showing vulnerability.
Responds to wife's encouragement by agreeing to try for a child despite doubts, showing willingness and commitment.
Tells his wife to take the cow and go home, choosing to face the quest alone which can indicate protective behavior but also distancing.
Hesitates but ultimately agrees to give Jack the beans, tries to be practical and cautious about the situation.
Expresses doubt and unease about the magic beans and the plan, questioning the logic behind it.
Shows uncertainty and emotional conflict about becoming a father, referencing his own father as a source of doubt.
Agrees to take responsibility and attempts to find the rest of the items on his own despite doubts, showing initiative and acceptance of his role.
Looks guiltily to his wife after giving the beans away, indicating internal conflict and possible lack of confidence.
Hears Little Red Riding Hood scream and draws his knife nervously to protect her.
Confronts and kills the wolf disguised as Granny, despite being squeamish and shaken afterward.
Feels shaken and expresses disbelief after killing the wolf, indicating sensitivity and remorse.
Draws his knife nervously and confronts the wolf disguised as Granny, slashing at it to stop the threat despite his fear.
Is visibly shaken and expresses disbelief at his own actions after confronting the wolf.
Refuses to help skin the beast, stating he is a baker, not a hunter.
Advises Little Red Riding Hood to be more careful, showing concern for her safety.
Refuses to help skin the beast, stating 'I'm a baker,' showing awareness of his own limits and not overextending himself.
Leaves Granny's house clearly shaken and says 'I can't believe I just did that.', indicating self-doubt and emotional instability.
Cuts open the wolf to rescue Granny and LRRH, bringing them to safety.
Takes LRRH's hand gently after rescuing her.
Hesitates or questions before accepting LRRH's gift (the cape).
Cuts open the wolf's stomach to rescue Little Red Riding Hood and Granny, bringing them to light and safety.
Hesitates briefly when offered the cape from Little Red Riding Hood, showing caution before accepting.
Peacefully asleep, clutching the red cape like a blankie, showing vulnerability.
Skeptical but not dismissive when Jack shows him the five gold pieces, questioning rather than rejecting.
Is peacefully asleep and skeptical upon being woken by Jack who announces giants in the sky and shows gold coins.
Hesitates and tries to stop Jack from rushing into a decision about selling Milky-White, indicating concern and thoughtfulness.
Does not assert himself firmly when Jack ignores his hesitation, showing passivity or difficulty in communicating effectively.
Hesitates and attempts to communicate reservations about selling Milky-White but is interrupted and ignored.
Shows some caution and reluctance before rushing into a deal without fully asserting his position.
Hides the money sack and questions his wife about the red cape and cow, showing concern and protectiveness.
Gets angry at his wife for losing Milky-White, expressing frustration but still focused on the situation.
Offers the red cape to the Witch despite the Witch’s hostility, showing willingness to cooperate.
Comments 'I don't like that woman' after the Witch's harsh treatment, expressing his dislike sincerely.
Hides the money sack when colliding into his wife, tries to be cautious and protective of resources.
Insists on the correct number of items left, showing awareness and tracking of their goals.
Gets angry and blameful at his wife for losing the cow, showing frustration but no clear problem-solving.
Offers the cape to the Witch immediately in an attempt to fulfill the Witch's demands.
Gets dirt and muck thrown on him by the Witch without reacting or countering, suggesting passivity.
Admits he shouldn't have yelled, speaks firmly but kindly, intends to make things right, and urges his wife to leave for her safety.
Takes responsibility for his mistake by deciding to make things right and firmly instructs his wife to return to the village, showing resolve and focus.
Searches for Milky-White, appearing disheveled and exhausted, showing concern and diligence.
Politely asks the Stepsisters to compare an ear of corn with their hair, demonstrating politeness and a friendly approach despite their screaming.
Searching for Milky-White in the woods despite being disheveled and exhausted.
Flagging down the carriage and confidently hopping on the sideboard to negotiate.
Persistently continues quest despite being pushed off carriage and sitting on the cow, showing resilience and dedication.
Brags about having the cow and limited progress, showing pride yet a playful, open interaction with his wife.
Engages in cooperative dialogue with his wife, showing willingness to share the task and admit need for partnership.
Recognizes and admires his wife's contribution, encouraging teamwork ('We've one entire day left', 'perhaps it will take the two of us').
Recovers from being pushed off the carriage and continues the quest without giving up.
Accidentally sits on the cow, Milky-White, showing a brief moment of carelessness.
Successfully compares the wife's braid to the ear of corn to confirm the match, demonstrating observational skill.
Counts and keeps track of the magical items obtained, showing a clear understanding of their progress.
Shows some uncertainty about whether his wife will stay, but is open to collaboration.
Acknowledges that change and partnership take care, patience, and shared effort; expresses awareness and acceptance of their joint responsibility in the relationship.
Flirts playfully with his wife, showing a tender and affectionate attitude despite difficulties.
Shows awareness that cooperation and shared effort are needed to overcome challenges together with his wife.
Acknowledges difficulty and lack of fun in the journey but maintains a committed, patient approach to problem-solving.
Becomes more open-hearted, considerate, charming, clever and confident in the woods, demonstrating personal growth and adaptability.
Does not display any lack of skill or understanding; rather he embraces challenges and the necessity of partnership effectively.
Stops Jack's golden egg from rolling away and engages calmly with Jack and his wife.
Disputes over the five gold pieces with Jack, showing a sense of fairness and protecting his family's interest.
Stops the golden egg rolling down and picks it up promptly.
Engages in negotiation about the cow and the five gold pieces, showing awareness but some confusion or miscommunication.
Looks up and notices the shadow moving across the moon, indicating awareness of time running out to reverse the Witch's curse.
Reacts to Milky-White's death with alarm but does not show immediate panic, instead focuses on the urgency of the situation.
Uses a defensive denial ('No, no, no - it's not how it sounds!') when confronted, which may reflect a lack of clear communication or confidence.
Engages cooperatively with his wife in planning their tasks and expresses concern about their separation.
Snaps a branch roughly while moving through the woods.
Snaps a branch blocking his path while navigating the woods, demonstrating proactive problem-solving and physical capability.
Expresses uncertainty about where to start and where to buy a cow, indicating a lack of knowledge or planning.
Engages in practical discussion with his wife about their tasks, showing willingness to coordinate and strategize.
Questions why they always have to separate, which may reflect insecurity or indecisiveness about their strategy.
Narrates the violent and cruel actions of the Stepmother without intervening or expressing condemnation.
Encourages the cow to keep moving, showing perseverance and patience.
Shares success with Wife, expresses delight and cooperation.
Admits to deceiving the Witch by covering the cow with flour to simulate whiteness, tries to justify with honesty.
Helps feed the revived cow despite difficulty in feeding it.
Looks up at the moon attentively, signaling concern about time.
Recognizes the urgency of the situation and participates in feeding the cow the necessary ingredients despite difficulty.
Looks up at the moon and notes the approaching midnight deadline, demonstrating awareness of time constraints.
Relies on the Witch's magical ability without showing independent problem solving or control over the situation.
Carefully compares the hair with an ear of corn to verify ingredients, demonstrating diligence and honesty.
Moans along with Wife when realizing a mistake was made, showing shared concern and emotional sincerity.
Observes with relief and makes a light-hearted comment about his wife's pregnancy growing quickly.
Observes the rapid pregnancy of his wife and responds with a lighthearted comment ('That was quick!') indicating awareness and attentiveness to unfolding events.
Describes events in voice-over that outline resolution and success of the quest, implying reflection and understanding of outcomes.
Expresses concern for his wife and baby after the earthquake shaking the castle.
Shows concern for his wife and baby after the earthquake, calmly checking if they are alright despite being stunned.
Is stunned by the sudden chaos, momentarily showing shock and surprise.
Gently greets Little Red Riding Hood and expresses concern about her situation.
Offers practical help to Little Red Riding Hood to find her Granny's cottage despite the confusing changes in the woods.
Greets Little Red Riding Hood calmly and offers help navigating the changed woods despite uncertainty.
Responds empathetically and tries to reassure Little Red Riding Hood in a confusing situation.
Does not immediately know the solution to the lost path problem but demonstrates willingness to assist.
Uncomfortable holding the baby but tries to care for him, offers to take care of him when older.
Acknowledges the baby's preference for mother rather than rejecting the baby.
Protectively puts his arm around his wife during the frightening event.
Hands the crying baby back quickly, showing some discomfort and possible avoidance.
Calmly identifies the threat as a giant woman and answers questions truthfully about the lad’s whereabouts, maintaining composure in a tense and dangerous situation.
Does not take immediate action to protect the group or negotiate with the giant beyond stating they haven’t seen the lad.
Steps forward, taking charge and urging everyone to stick together.
Tells others 'Don't upset the Giant!'
Steps forward, taking charge, and calls for unity to face the Giant threat.
Allows others to deceive the Giant by giving false information about the boy's location (implied by the Steward and others' statements).
Takes charge and encourages unity by saying 'If we're going to get through this we have to stick together.'
Promises Jack's mother that he will not let them get Jack.
Insists that his wife should not go alone to search for Jack, expressing concern for safety.
Reluctantly lets his wife go but gives her his scarf to keep warm, showing care and thoughtfulness.
Questions the decision to leave the baby with Little Red Riding Hood due to worry about safety, showing protectiveness.
Wife states she came with her husband (the Baker) but chose to roam alone in the woods, implying trust and permisiveness in their relationship.
The Wife's interruption to rebuff the Prince's advances by affirming loyalty to her husband (the Baker).
His wife chooses to go alone into the woods while he stays behind, indicating possible reluctance or inability to face dangers directly.
The wife refers to him proudly as 'a baker', implying he is a stable and reliable provider, though not necessarily a heroic figure.
Notices Cinderella crying and offers help sincerely despite confusion.
Speaks frankly about the Prince’s likely untrustworthy behavior without bitterness.
Politely approaches Cinderella to offer help despite confusion about the situation.
Mistakes the cause of the disaster (thinks it's not an earthquake but a giant), showing some misunderstanding of events.
Demonstrates social awareness by noticing Cinderella's distress and responds with empathy.
Recognizes Cinderella despite her disguise and humbly apologizes for not recognizing her immediately.
Offers safety and companionship to Cinderella, inviting her to come with him.
Recognizes Cinderella despite her disguise and respectfully bows to her, then offers protection and safe passage.
Paces anxiously waiting for the Wife to return, expresses concern and desire to search for her.
Demands the Witch to release Jack when she is hurting him.
Shouts at the Witch to stop and protects Jack from her.
Shows concern by picking up Jack's dropped scarf and recognizes it as his wife's, indicating his care and connection.
Expresses sorrow and guilt for letting his wife wander off alone, showing self-blame and emotional openness.
Angrily confronts the Witch after learning his wife is dead.
Blames Jack repeatedly for the problems and conflict.
Explains his family's curse and situation openly.
Argues logically about the worth of the magic beans and the consequences of their trade, trying to clarify the cause of the problems.
Blames Jack and others without fully resolving the conflict or taking decisive action to fix the situation.
Maintains firm stance and tries to mediate the blame game by pointing to facts and motives behind the actions.
Admits to taking the other bean and clarifies he gave it to his wife, ultimately redirects responsibility to Cinderella with a reasonable explanation.
Tries to clarify responsibility logically by connecting the sequence of events involving the beans and exchanges, attempting to deflect blame and identify the real issue.
Contradicts himself by first denying pocketing the bean and then admitting it, showing some confusion.
Demonstrates some reasoning skills by pointing out that Cinderella is the only one who knows what happened to the bean after exchanging it for the shoe.
Attempts to understand who is responsible amid the blame-shifting among others.
Joins in the mutual blaming among characters instead of calming the situation.
Attempts to mediate and clarify the situation by questioning Cinderella and acknowledging the harp issue. Shows some initiative in engaging with the conflict.
Fails to resolve the blame game or take control of the escalating argument, allowing others to accuse each other with no clear leadership or solution.
Joins others in blaming the Witch for their predicament.
Receives his baby from the Witch, showing trust and protective responsibility.
Argues with others by blaming them instead of taking responsibility for the trouble.
Holds the baby handed to him by the Witch without apparent panic or hesitation.
Bitterly criticizes others and abruptly leaves despite the group's need for help.
Hands the baby to Cinderella before leaving, showing some trust and care.
Holds the baby calmly after a catastrophic event, showing steadiness.
Hands the baby to Cinderella and states he's leaving, showing decision and taking responsibility for his own course of action.
Responds bitterly and dismissively to others' regrets and pleas for cooperation, refusing to engage or help.
Rejects group effort and decides to act alone despite the complexity of the situation.
Acknowledges dependence on his wife and the pain of leaving his child for the child's happiness.
Responds despondently and begins to walk off, avoiding further confrontation with Cinderella.
Expresses anger and resentment toward his father, refusing forgiveness and showing emotional distance.
Engages in a tense but honest conversation with his father about past mistakes and consequences.
Acknowledges his dependence on his wife for everything, showing lack of self-reliance.
Despondently decides to leave his child in the care of a princess, demonstrating avoidance and low confidence.
Walks aimlessly through the woods alone, indicating uncertainty and lack of direction.
Confronts his father and expresses anger and disappointment clearly and directly.
Listens silently when his father questions if he is making the same mistake, showing some internal reflection.
Breaks down emotionally holding his wife's scarf, then calms himself.
Returns determined to reclaim and comfort his baby son, pulls him close to soothe him.
Asserts they need to work together to rid the kingdom of the Giant, showing willingness to cooperate.
Calms himself after breaking down emotionally, then returns determined to act.
Takes the baby from Cinderella to comfort it, showing protective and decisive behavior.
Organizes a plan to rid the kingdom of the Giant using bait and coordinating allies.
Gently informs Jack of his mother's death with care and attempts to temper Jack's anger and desire for revenge.
Attempts to dissuade Jack from seeking violent retribution against the Steward.
Communicates difficult truths to Jack calmly and attempts to dissuade him from rash vengeance.
Admits the complexity of the situation rather than oversimplifying moral issues.
Fails to immediately provide a clear solution or plan in a tense emotional moment.
Reassures Cinderella that she is not alone and that someone is on her side.
Acknowledges that people make mistakes and encourages understanding and fighting for one another despite imperfections.
Urges Jack to be careful in the face of danger, showing concern for others' safety.
Offers reassurance and shared wisdom about mistakes and support, showing emotional intelligence and leadership.
Encourages Jack to be careful facing the approaching giant, demonstrating situational awareness and protective instincts.
Coordinates with Jack to prepare a slingshot attack on the Giant, demonstrates readiness and situational awareness.
Maintains focus under pressure, continues to fire stones accurately at the Giant.
Crawls out from beneath the tree branch, despite being scratched up and breathless, showing persistence and ability to survive the accident.
Calls out and helps Jack when he is trapped and in need of help, demonstrating leadership and responsiveness in a crisis.
Hesitates before inviting others to live with him, indicating some uncertainty or lack of decisiveness in social leadership.
Eventually warmly invites the others to stay with him and embrace the idea of shared future cooperation.
Comforts and soothes his crying baby by wrapping a scarf around him and holding him close despite his own uncertainty about fatherhood.
Expresses self-doubt and insecurity about being a father due to lack of guidance from his own father.
Holds his son close and soothes him, calming the baby for the first time in his arms.
Tells his son a story emphasizing caution and care, demonstrating concern for his son's understanding and growth.
Tells the story carefully and reflects on past events to his son, showing awareness and intention to teach lessons learned.
Repeats the story without addition or adaptation, possibly indicating a lack of new insight or growth.
